awd_titl_txt: Design of oligozulene-based organometallics for probing new paradigms in charge delocalization, transport, and storage at the nanoscopic scale
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Mikhail V. Barybin of the University of Kansas is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the Division of Chemistry to design, synthesize and characterize azulene-based molecules (combination of 5- and 7-membered carbon rings) that are capable of electric charge transport.  The goal is to develop molecules with improved functionality relevant to organic electronic, computer, optoelectronic, and energy storage (battery) applications.   A major emphasis is placed on targeting molecules comprised of multiple azulenic units to enable efficient molecular charge transport and rectification.  Such molecules offer the potential of creating ultra-small molecular components for electronic devices that function with minimal power consumption.  This project improves our understanding of charge transport through single molecules.  It also affords a platform for the development of functional materials with surfaces modified by self-assembled monolayers.  The award supports training of graduate and undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary research environment.  A partnership with Clayton State University (a primarily undergraduate institution with a predominantly African American student base) attracts students from underrepresented minority and involves them in the project.  The PI brings a first-hand perspective on challenges faced by science students and faculty affected by a chronic illness in pursuit of their educational and professional aspirations.  By showcasing the scientific and human resource development outcomes of the project at professional conferences and less formal community-centered venues, the PI's advocacy highlights societal benefits of enhancing the diversity of university campuses through inclusion of persons with chronic illnesses.

In this project, synthetic, computational, electrochemical, spectroscopic and surface chemistry techniques are synergistically employed to develop nonbenzenoid, aromatic azulene-based platform that exhibit redox, electronic, and optoelectronic properties, typically inaccessible through the use of benzenoid aromatics.  The molecules are designed to have anchoring groups, such as mercapto and isocyano, capable of self assembly on surfaces without affecting the azulenic scaffold's aromaticity.  DFT calculations are used to inform the design of the azulenic molecules.  The products are characterized and tested as potential components in nanoelectronic devices.  The specific aims are: (1) to design asymmetrically anchored organic linkers that feature key structural rigidity and spatial separation of the bridge's frontier molecular orbitals; (2) to evaluate the conductivity/rectification profiles and the electron transfer dynamics in azulene self-assembled monolayers; and (3) to construct molecular electron reservoirs composed of azulene-based organometallic nanocomplexes with at least 12-electron reversible organic redox capacity, and to examine their charge delocalization potential, including organic intervalence coupling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Molecules capable of transporting and/or storing electric charge offer the potential of creating devices that operate with very little power and have ultra-small footprints. In this project, Professor Mikhail Barybin of the University Kansas (KU) and his research team established new molecular design principles for tuning and improving functionality of compounds and materials relevant to organic electronics, optoelectronics, and possibly molecular battery applications. The new compounds and self-assembled molecular monolayer films synthesized and studied by the Barybin group involve molecular linkers comprised of azulenic scaffolds (edge-sharing combinations 5- and 7-membered carbon rings).  For example, among the key outcomes of this research was access to well-defined molecular electrochromic systems that can reversibly gain 12 electrons and lose up to 9 electrons per molecule, thereby supporting the molecular charge variation of up to 21 units. Moreover, the quantitative insights into tuning electronic characteristics of azulenic and polyazulenic molecular wires and molecular electron reservoirs that emerged from this NSF-sponsored project will facilitate rational design of new functional materials at the nanoscopic scale.

The broader impacts of this project include training of graduate and undergraduate students in a highly collaborative interdisciplinary research environment, and providing in-depth research experiences to seven undergraduates, two of whom were African-American students from Clayton State University (a minority serving primarily undergraduate institution located in Morrow, GA). Five of these undergraduate researchers are currently pursuing their doctoral graduate degrees in chemistry. In addition, the Barybin research group donated a diverse collection of samples of structurally unusual azulenic substances prepared in this project for use in the inquiry-driven teaching Lab “Tuning Color through Substitution at the Azulenic Ring,” which is a part of the Honors general chemistry curriculum at the University of Kansas. Chemistry faculty from other colleges and universities across the nation continued to express interest in implementing the azulene-based Tuning Color through Substitution concepts in their own undergraduate chemistry laboratory curricula.

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2023
Modified by: Mikhail V Barybin
